title: VC Daily: Venture Investors Back Ribbon Health With $43.5 Million
text:
For example, a Medicare review of healthcare-provider directories of Medicare Advantage organizations, conducted in 2016 and 2017, found that 52.2% of the locations listed had at least one inaccuracy, such as physicians who don't practice at the site. Medical practices often list a doctor as being at a location because the group has an office there, even if that physician rarely or never sees patients at that site, according to Medicare.

Founded in 2016, Ribbon aggregates physician data, such as phone numbers and insurances accepted, and uses machine learning to figure out which information is correct, said co-founder and Chief Executive Nate Maslak. This, for instance, could help a health insurer improve its directory of healthcare providers, he said.

Ribbon plans to apply this new funding to areas such as technology investment and hiring. It plans to increase its headcount to nearly 150 by the end of 2022 from 60 today, Mr. Maslak said.

And now on to the news ...

Top News

A view of State Street in downtown Boston where the Massachusetts Pension Reserves Investment Management Board is based.

Co-investments. The Massachusetts Pension Reserves Investment Management Board wants to double the amount of capital it commits to co-investments, where the pension invests in deals alongside its general partners, without paying them extra fees or a share of the profits, The Wall Street Journal's Preeti Singh reports.

The investment committee for Mass PRIM, as the $98.5 billion pension is known, approved a recommendation that would give the investment staff flexibility to commit up to 40% of its annual private-equity allocation to co-investments. The pace is double the 20% of annual commitments that the pension currently sets aside for such deals. The pension system's board of trustees is expected to vote on the plan in December.

Mass PRIM has allocated between $2.1 billion and $2.7 billion for new private-equity investments in 2021. So far this year through its August board meeting, the pension had committed $2.234 billion to 17 private-equity funds, the documents from the committee meeting show.

Mass PRIM joins a number of large investors that are increasing their focus on private-equity co-investments, which help them reduce costs associated with their private-equity portfolios and forge closer ties to their favorite managers. Unlike with private-equity funds, investors typically pay no fees or carried interest on co-investment deals.

$250 Million

The amount of Series B financing raised by biotechnology startup Acelyrin Inc.

AI Customer-Service Startup Netomi Raises $30 Million

Netomi Inc., a provider of customer-service chatbots, said it has raised $30 million in a Series B funding round that values the company at $210 million, up from a valuation of $67.5 million in 2019. Netomi customers use the company's chatbots to automate customer-service conversations in venues including email, messaging and virtual assistants. The company is based in San Mateo, Calif., with additional offices in New York City and Gurugram, India.

Goldman CEO Calls China, Hong Kong Covid-19 Policies a ‘Headwind for Global Talent'

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Chief Executive David Solomon said mainland China and Hong Kong's strict border controls are creating staffing challenges, as the region's tight quarantine regime wears on foreign workers and businesses. "Certainly, being restricted in terms of leaving or coming back, the family pressure, etc., that's not a great dynamic for talent," Mr. Solomon said Wednesday. "That's certainly a headwind for global talent in that part of the world, right at this moment."

WSJ Pro is hosting the Sustainable Business Forum on Nov. 17. The program includes an innovation showcase with AB InBev, Keurig Dr Pepper and City Developments Ltd. and a presentation by Jonah Goldman, managing director at Breakthrough Energy. Register here.

Industry News

Funds

European technology investor Balderton Capital raised $600 million for its newest early-stage fund. The London-based firm's recent investments include event ticketing platform vivenu GmbH, payments infrastructure provider Primer and virtual events startup Hubilo Technologies Inc.

LiveOak Venture Partners closed its third fund above its hard cap with $210 million in commitments. The new fund will continue the firm's strategy of backing Texas-based companies with initial investments in the $1 million to $5 million range, and scaling up to $15 million over the full lifecycle of the company. Austin-based LiveOak raised $105 million for its second fund in 2019.

European life sciences investor Sofinnova Partners raised €150 million (about $170 million) for its third industrial biotech fund dedicated to environmental impact, bringing the firm's total assets under management to €2.5 billion. Sofinnova Industrial Biotech II will continue to invest in early-stage companies harnessing biotechnology to develop sustainable solutions across the food, agriculture, chemical and materials sectors.

People

Andreessen Horowitz appointed James Gwertzman as a new general partner and also promoted Jonathan Lai to general partner. Mr. Gwertzman founded PlayFab, which was acquired by Microsoft. Before a16z, Mr. Lai was at Tencent, where he led the North America games investments team.

Toronto-based Radical Ventures, which focuses on artificial intelligence investments in Canada and the U.S., named John Megrue as partner and vice chairman. He was previously co-chairman of Bridgewater and worked at Apax Partners.

EquityZen, an online marketplace for trading pre-IPO employee shares, appointed Eric Bernstein as chief operating officer. He was previously president at Broadridge Asset Management Solutions. New York-based EquityZen is backed by investors including Draper Associates and WorldQuant Ventures.

Exits

NCino Inc. seeks to expand its point-of-sale and mobile capabilities with an agreement to buy SimpleNexus in a cash-and-stock deal valued at roughly $1.2 billion. Early this year, Lehi, Utah-based SimpleNexus raised a $108 million Series B round led by Insight Partners.

Hilti Group agreed to acquire Fieldwire, a jobsite management platform for the construction industry, for approximately $300 million. San Francisco-based Fieldwire has raised funding from Menlo Ventures, Brick and Mortar Ventures, Formation 8 and Bloomberg Beta.

Fintech company Oportun Financial Corp. agreed to acquire Digit, a neobanking platform that provides automated savings, investing and banking tools, for $98.5 million in equity and $114.4 million in cash. Digit is backed by investors including General Catalyst, Ribbit Capital, GV and Citi Ventures.

U.S. Bancorp will acquire expense and travel management platform TravelBank for an undisclosed amount. San Francisco-based TravelBank is backed by investors including DCM Ventures, Propel Venture Partners, DHVC, New Enterprise Associates, Accel and Silicon Valley Bank.

New Money

Heyday, a San Francisco-based brand building platform, closed a $555 million Series C round. The Raine Group and Premji Invest co-led the funding, which included participation from General Catalyst, Victory Park Capital and Khosla Ventures. In addition to the investment, Heyday added Navid Veiseh as chief financial officer, Reema Batta as chief marketing officer and Todd Heeter as chief accounting officer.

Upgrade Inc., a San Francisco-based credit and mobile banking services provider, secured $280 million in Series F funding at a $6 billion pre-money valuation. Coatue Management and DST Global led the round, which included contributions from Dragoneer Investment Group, Gopher Asset Management, G Squared, Koch Disruptive Technologies, Ribbit Capital, Sands Capital, Ventura Capital and Vy Capital.

OpenStore, a Miami-based startup that acquires Shopify businesses and gives entrepreneurs liquidity, nabbed a $75 million Series B round. General Catalyst led the new funding, which included support from Atomic, Founders Fund and Khosla Ventures.

AnyDesk, a German provider of remote desktop software, fetched more than $70 million in Series C financing, bringing the company's valuation up to $660 million. General Atlantic led the round, which saw participation from Insight Partners, EQT Ventures and Possible Ventures.

Justt, a Tel Aviv-based chargeback mitigation startup, emerged from stealth with $70 million in funding across three tranches led by Oak HC/FT, Zeev Ventures and F2 Venture Capital.

EasySend, a Tel Aviv-based startup that helps insurance carriers, banks and financial institutions to digitize manual, paper-based processes, nabbed $50.5 million in Series B financing. Oak HC/FT led the round, which saw participation from Vertex Ventures Israel, Intel Capital and Hanaco Venture Capital. In addition to the Series B funding, EasySend raised $5 million in venture debt from Silicon Valley Bank.

Alluxio Inc., a San Mateo, Calif.-based developer of open-source data orchestration software for the cloud, secured $50 million in Series C financing from investors including Andreessen Horowitz, Seven Seas Partners and Volcanics Ventures.

PlanetScale Inc., a Mountain View, Calif.-based serverless database platform, grabbed $50 million in Series C funding. Kleiner Perkins led the investment, with Partner Bucky Moore joining the board. Andreessen Horowitz, SignalFire, Insight Partners and others also contributed to the round.

StarkWare, an Israeli blockchain technology startup, picked up a $50 million Series C investment led by Sequoia Capital, valuing the company at $2 billion.

People Data Labs Inc., a San Francisco startup whose technology enables developers, engineers and data scientists to build data-driven products, raised $45 million in Series B funding. Led by Craft Ventures, the round included support from Flex Capital. Jeff Fluhr, co-founder and general partner of Craft Ventures, will join the company's board.

Hightouch, a San Francisco-based startup that syncs customer data to various SaaS tools, snagged $40 million in Series B funding at a $450 million valuation. Lead investor Iconiq Growth was joined by Amplify Partners, Bain Capital Ventures, Y Combinator and Afore Capital in the round.

Stellar Cyber, a Santa Clara, Calif.-based threat detection and incident response platform, landed $38 million in an oversubscribed Series B round. Highland Capital Partners led the investment, which included additional support from Valley Capital Partners, SIG, Northern Light Venture Capital and Samsung.

Qualcomm shares rise to record high on ambitious growth targets

Cardinal Health to test drone delivery to pharmacies

How DeFi hopes to disrupt traditional finance

Around the Web
